Do you think it was good for XRP to settle their dispute with SEC?

Yes, The SEC is formidable as they do their homework. Before any suit against any company, the SEC has done exhaustive and extensive investigations to prove all allegations against a companies. Therefore, the SEC tends to win its cases.

Most companies’ legal teams know this and advise their corporate clients to simply settle. The SEC takes its time to build the cases. It never files frivolous suits.

The SEC protects the little guy and readers should take the time to visit the SEC website and read what the SEC publishes for the retail investors and retail traders.

Why is Spotify stock in decline?
Originally Answered: Why did Spotify’s stock drop in value?

Spotify has been in a minor intermediate term correction since mid February. The news that it was selling Exchangeable Senior notes *corporate bonds that can be exchanged for cash or stock. These notes are unsecured and only sold to Institutions on a private transaction. The notes do not pay regular interest and the principal amount will not accrete which in the financial world means to have growth of this debt value.

This caused a sell down further. However, the company has had other financial problems. for the year 2020 revenues grew well but earnings were severely more negative. This the bond sale is a signal of further deterioration of the financial conditions of the company and these are not favorable notes to Institutional investors. The stock was already under heavy Rotation to Lower Inventory by large Buy Side Institutions since last October. The Percentage of Shares Held by Institutions is below 60 which is very low for a young company.

However, the company is near a significant support level where Institutions had previously accumulated the stock and that may provide a level where a bottoming formation can begin or a trading range sideways pattern. The company is young and companies all face business contraction cycles from time to time.

Below is the full lifetime chart of SPOT from its IPO in 2018 to current on a Weekly Chart. Green Lines are Support Levels based on Dark Pool Giant Buy Side previous accumulation at that level. That level represent fundamental support for the stock price.

Below the price chart the Cycle Indicator shows the earliest stages of a Trough for the business cycle.

All companies have cycles. The duration of that cycle depends on the industry as well as the individual corporation. The company is young and so long as it is not acquired has a long life ahead of it.

Is pursuing investing in the stock market using Revolut really free? How do they make money then?

The brokers make their income either from selling you stock out of inventory and profiting from the sales OR they sell your orders to other financial companies that either route and or fill the order. All of these transactions profit from your purchase of the stock. Citadel bought Robinhood app customer orders when Robinhood sold those orders to that firm as one example.

The brokers make more money selling their customer orders than they did charging their retail customers charges for each transaction, thus your fills are still in the NBBO National Best Bid Offer at the time of the fill but the way it is done provides for higher revenues to the brokerages.

Yes they also make money on margin accounts IF you have a margin account and if you use it. Usually long term investors would not use a margin account. Margin accounts are generally used only for high risk trades, selling short, and day tradnig.

Will the SEC have to pay a fine if it loses its case against Ripple XRP and Glaringhouse? If not, why not? If so, how much?

The SEC is a regulatory entity that enforces the laws, rules, and regulations of the stock market. It is obligated to press charges and file suits against any company or entity that has or appears to have violated any law, rule or regulation of the stock market.

Therefore it is not going to be fined if the lawsuit goes in favor of Ripple. It is extremely rare for the SEC to not win a case in court, hence few go to court. Usually if they proceed to court there is substantial evidence to prove the case.

REITS for low capital investments in Real Estate of any kind.

Soon you will be able to invest in a cargo ship tokenized, or the inventories of a huge company, or other amazing new assets that will be traded on the stock market under the classification of Derivatives.

Why do companies care about their stock price after they IPOed, since they don't generate any revenue from the change in stock prices after that?

This is an excellent question. The reason why companies place so much importance on their stock prices relate to their Market Capitalization. Market Cap which it is often referred to is in the most basic of explanations: the price of the stock times the outstanding shares.

This is many things to a public corporation.

  1. The Larger the company Market Cap the more important that company is in terms of the stock market and its influence as a major corporation.
  2. Every company’s CEO dreams of having the Largest Market Cap company or the largest company in the world based on market cap. AAPL held the title for a while. TSLA had the title for a while and many others over the years. Such standing as the largest public corporation in the world is a status symbol of being the best at that moment.
  3. Corporations rely upon their Market Cap to lure more and more investors to buy their stock, believing it is one of the Great American Companies. Most retail investors are leery of small cap stocks because they fear the company is too small for investing, or will never become a great company. Usually the demand for stock comes with a rising Market Cap.
  4. Investors view the large cap companies as the safest and most trustworthy investments. This also is huge for a company. The firm can buyback shares of stock to tighten the outstanding shares quantities and thereby raise the stock value itself or by having more investors want to buy the stock.
  5. Corporate Bonds, especially Convertible Bolds rely on the value of Market Cap. Companies with large market cap are going to have a better demand for their corporate bonds, regardless of type of bond. Bonds are how a company can infuse more capital into the company for more growth. Bonds also aid during times of market stress so maintaining good Market Cap via stock prices rising is a big deal.
  6. in 2018–2019 the largest corporations began a massive buyback individually but in tandem. Thus about 4 trillion estimate of corporate cash and in 2019 tax cut savings cash went into buybacks. This was such a massive program at that time with so many corporations spending billions of dollars on buybacks that the corporations were able to hold the market up in a trading range that held until 2020, when the market collapsed. Between the end of 2017 and 2020 the indexes which represent the “stock market to most retail investors did not show a bear market, even though the majority of stocks were in a bear business cycle. Thus for the first time, corporations were able to avoid a huge loss of value on their stock by using billion in cash to keep their stock up while the Giant Buy Side Institutions were selling slowly over those 3 years due to the bear business cycles of many companies.
  7. Corporations have learned that keeping their stock prices moving upward is important and can forestall a bear market. Corporations continue to use buybacks at this time to avoid really low market cap that would cause Raiders and Hostile Takeovers that would put the company out of business.

There are 2 (TWO) primary products that every company has”

  1. Its products or services it sells to either businesses or consumers or both. This is what generates the revenues for operations, payroll, development of new products, etc.
  2. Its STOCK which doesn’t generate revenues for the company after its IPO but does define the status, importance, and influence of that public corporation in the US economy and globally. That status is invaluable and vitally important as only the top 500 corporations make it onto the S&P500 index out of some 5800 current listed stocks. Companies will use dividends to keep investors in their stock.

Corporations strive to find ways to keep their stock price upward. However all stocks retrace, correct, and have bear cycles. Corporation know that if a bear cycle occurs it will lose investors both the Giant Buy Side and the individual retail investors. Investors are a crucial aspect of the public corporation.

What useful information is not available to retail investors about a stock while it is readily available for institutional investors?

Institutional Investors aka Buy Side Institutions approach their investing with knowledge that can be obtained by retail investors but is not because the retail investors are unaware that this knowledge and information is available and critically important.

What Buy Side Institutions understand that retail investors do not is business in general.

I often repeat that all businesses have cycles. But most investors have no idea what I really mean by a business bear cycle or a business bull cycle, annual cycles versus long term cycles and so on. Since the Institutions understand business cycles in-depth and depend on these cycles as guidelines to monitor the company for changes or deviations of the cycle OR a weakening of financials that foretells of the end of a bull business cycle, the institutions are able to slowly rotate out of a stock, lowering their inventory of that stock to reduce the impact on their mutual, pension, or index funds.

The Buy Side also is more attentive to the activity of the company, the CEO, what projects are underway for reinvention, new technology, etc. They do visit the corporations that they are most heavily vested in and often do walk arounds listening to the CEO and CFO about how the company is growing, dealing with covid, or considering a merger, or new market in another country, or a new service. This information is not available to the average investor as if you only own 100 shares of stock, the CEO is not going to take the time to talk to you as an investor, even though you may have the right to ask.

This means you need to depend upon fundamental indicators that are NOT promoted or used by retail investors which are the indicators that tell you whether the Buy Side institutions are accumulating, rotating to lower inventory, or distribution mode of their inventory of shares for that company. This is simple and easy information to obtain quarterly.

Usually the Institution knows well ahead of time, often a couple of weeks, how well the corporation has done for the upcoming earnings reporting season. Again following the activity of the Buy Side Institutions generally can give you a reasonable idea of what to expect. No, the Institutions do not worry about the company “beating estimates” because that is a retail side data that is not worth much. All companies provide data to the retail analysts who deliberately make sure that the company is capable of beating those estimates. IF a company is not going to beat it estimates, it knows this before the final month so it warns or advises early, long before the earnings report date. AND then the analysts lower their estimates so that the company can “beat estimates”. It is basically a carefully adjusted data set that doesn’t mean anything.

One thing you must always remember is this: The Institutions are creating a product called either a Mutual Fund, an ETF, an Index fund, or other type of fund. They set an Alpha goal which is the ROI they know that they are highly likely to achieve most of the time. They are not trying to make the highest ROI possible. What they endeavor to do is provide a lower ROI that is consistent so that investors continue to hold their product as long term investments.

Most Giant Mutual Funds hold a huge number of different listed companies. Their largest holdings will be top performers in the industry upon which the fund is based or the index upon which the fund is based.

Therefore, the ROI that Institutions assure their investors is likely, or the target ROI, is generally met unless there is some catastrophic unknown and unforeseeable event. When there is a bear market, the Institutions use a variety of hedging and mitigating technics to attempt to limit the risk to the ROI expectations. These are no longer hedge funds for many of the largest fund companies. Instead they use e-minis, futures, and stock options as insurance policies to reduce risk while holding through the event or until they can lower inventories to reduce the risk.

What the Buy Side Institutions do for investors is complex, far beyond what you might imagine. Many have trading floors with traders trading short term and this too affects some ROI.

There are so many things the Institutions can do to stay one step ahead of the companies they hold in inventory I could write a book about it. But these few provide you with some insight as to how these silent, hidden Giants do the business of protecting the vast wealth of the US middle class.

Does the economy affect the stock market?
Originally Answered: Do stock markets really depend on the economy?

The Stock Market is dependent upon the listed public companies that are the stock market for that country.

Publicly Traded corporations include all the largest companies in the US plus many ADS corporations that are also listed on the US exchanges but are registered in a different country.

The stock market also has the publicly traded mid cap companies that are either older big blue chip stocks or companies midway in their growth life cycles.

The stock market also has many small cap companies that are either aging companies that are slowly ending their life and will either go bankrupt or merge as well as all the very young new IPOs.

These firms create the economy of the US along with the some 30 million small businesses which includes the 22 million sole proprietors.

Combined, all of these business represent and create the economy of the US. The sole proprietors often provide services that public companies need.

Therefore, the businesses of the US are the economy of the US. None of these figures include any government entity as none are publicly traded.

The stock market is NOT dependent upon the economy, rather, the economy is dependent upon the stock market. Without a stock market, there would be far fewer big corporations as it is impossible to finance the growth of a company without Venture Capital in the start-up years, then IPO capital from the stock market Initial Public Offering which gives most firms significant capital to grow for many years. Then Corporate Bonds would not be as prevalent as corporations that are not public have less opportunity to have the average investor American get to know the company.

The Stock Market provides a constant front page news for most companies of significance and many young startups which helps the company grow from a garage or basement or tiny one many office into giants like Amazon, Apple, Google and so on.

Without the public interest in owning shares of stock, enjoying the benefits of dividend investing, and the trading activity that further promotes the company, the economy of the US would not be what it is today: The Largest and most complex economy in the world.

The economy depends on the stock market, businesses, and investors more than anyone comprehends. That is WHY most nations have a stock market or are striving to create one.

Why are the retail and travel stocks more bullish than the pre-CoVID times?

One thing that is total misinformation right now is the notion that we are headed for a bear market. Folks that started in 2018 and was camouflaged by massive trillions of dollars of big corporate buybacks, and the tax cuts for corporations.

EVERY Pandemic in the history of the world has been followed by a huge growth in new technology and prosperity. I repeat, go do your homework. The Spanish Flu pandemic was followed by the Roaring Twenties huge economic prosperity for decade. And that is true of even the Black Plague pandemic of 1347–1351. Note the years of both pandemics were very similar although millennial apart. The Black plague was followed by the Great Renaissance.

The reason WHY retail and travel stocks and leisure stocks and any industry that is linked to these industries is gaining strength is the anticipation of the end to this pandemic, which may occur in less time the prior pandemics. There is a pent up demand and emotional need to have a vacation, eat a nice meal in your favorite restaurant, go to a theater live performance of movie, travel to a warm climate such as Hawaii and just hang out and sunbath. There is a pent up demand for social interaction, for a big hug and seeing family you haven’t seen in over a year.

There is also a backlog of orders of many things that retail consumers still want to buy.

Every Global pandemic has been followed by a huge economic era of prosperity. I have said this many times and you can go and read up on pandemics and discover this for yourself. History doesn’t repeat exactly, but it does repeat within a frame work of similarities.

There is no reason to believe that the economy of the US and the world won’t experience a similar growth as the 20’s or other eras. There is no reason to be glum or worried about the economy. There is plenty of consumer needs that are deep in the American culture.

You need to shirk off all this bad gloom and doom or you are going to miss out on some of the best stock bargains in the next couple of years. I said this in 2009 and most people did not believe it then. I am not being overly optimistic. I am studying history and using that information as a guideline. This is NOT a prediction, it is an historical fact based on empirical evidence.

The Stock Market provides a constant front page news for most companies of significance and many young startups which helps the company grow from a garage or basement or tiny one many office into giants like Amazon, Apple, Google and so on.

Without the public interest in owning shares of stock, enjoying the benefits of dividend investing, and the trading activity that further promotes the company, the economy of the US would not be what it is today: The Largest and most complex economy in the world.

The economy depends on the stock market, businesses, and investors more than anyone comprehends. That is WHY most nations have a stock market or are striving to create one.
